Description: Fresh anchovies are an oily fish that look and taste similar to sardines. They vary in size and can be bought either fresh or cured. Cured anchovies were originally left whole and packed in salt, but now they tend to be boned, cleaned and preserved in salt or oil and sold in cans or jars.
Fact: Anchovies are naturally one of the foodstuffs most richly endowed with the so-called fifth taste, umami, which enhances the flavour of the other ingredients in certain recipes.

Sustainability_Seafood_Box_Text.__cdata: This species is considered a good alternative by Monterey Bay Aquarium's Seafood Watch. It is an option, but there are concerns with how it's caught or farmed, or with the health of its habitat due to other human impacts.

Mercury_Standard_Text.__cdata: This seafood is low in mercury. You can consume a 6-oz. portion two or three times a week and still stay under the EPA's reference dose for mercury. Individuals who are pregnant, nursing, or feeding a young child should choose seafood low in mercury. Additional information is available from Stony Brook University's Gelfond Fund for Mercury Research & Outreach.

Omega_Seafood_Box_Text.__cdata: Milligrams per 6-oz. serving. The level of omega-3 fatty acids for this seafood is considered high because one serving per week meets or exceeds the minimum recommended by nutrition experts (250 mg/day).

Description: Commercial Arctic char typically weigh between 2 and 10 lb (1 and 4.5 kg). The flesh is fine flaked and medium firm. The colour is between light pink and deep red, and the taste is like something between trout and salmon
Fact: The biggest char farmer in Canada, which still produces only about 175 metric tons a year after being in operation more than 30 years

Sustainability_Seafood_Box_Text.__cdata: This species should be avoided for now, as recommended by Monterey Bay Aquarium's Seafood Watch. It is caught or farmed in ways that harm other marine life or the environment.

Mercury_Standard_Text.__cdata: This seafood is moderate in mercury. You can consume one 6-oz. portion a week and stay under the EPA's reference dose for mercury. Individuals who are pregnant, nursing, or feeding a young child should choose seafood low in mercury. Additional information is available from Stony Brook University's Gelfond Fund for Mercury Research & Outreach

Sustainability_Seafood_Box_Text.__cdata: This species is considered a good alternative by Monterey Bay Aquarium's Seafood Watch. It is an option, but there are concerns with how it's caught or farmed, or with the health of its habitat due to other human impacts.

Sustainability_Seafood_Box_Text.__cdata: This species should be avoided for now, as recommended by Monterey Bay Aquarium's Seafood Watch. It is caught or farmed in ways that harm other marine life or the environment.

Mercury_Standard_Text.__cdata: This seafood is high in mercury and consumption of it should be limited. Individuals who eat seafood more than two or three times per week, or are pregnant, nursing, or feeding a young child should choose seafood low in mercury. Additional information is available from Stony Brook University's Gelfond Fund for Mercury Research & Outreach.

Omega_Seafood_Box_Text.__cdata: Milligrams per 6-oz. serving. The level of omega-3 fatty acids for this seafood is considered adequate because two servings per week meets or exceeds the minimum recommended by nutrition experts (250 mg/day).
